H0.text: Heat flows from the tea to the ice when an ice cube is placed in a cup of hot tea.

H1.text: Cold flows from the ice to the tea when an ice cube is placed in a cup of hot tea.

H2.text: Cold flows from the ice, and heat flows from the tea is the statement that describes the transfer of energy when an ice cube is placed in a cup of hot tea.

H3.text: Heat flows simultaneously between the ice and the tea when an ice cube is placed in a cup of hot tea.

A4.text: Such spontaneous heat transfer always occurs from a region of high temperature to another region of lower temperature, as described in the second law of thermodynamics.

A5.text: When an object is at a different temperature from another body or its surroundings, heat flows so that the body and the surroundings reach the same temperature, at which point they are in thermal equilibrium.

A6.text: Heat does not spontaneously flow from a colder body to a hotter body.

A7.text: Heat may be extracted from a system by cooling, expansion, or extraction of matter.
